I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested knowledge and 
support technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to expand access to 
finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through financial technology (fintech) 
innovations. The TA will assist the Research Department of the People’s Bank of China (PBC). 
The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2019–2021 for the PRC.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Economic importance of small and medium-sized enterprises. As in most developed 
and developing countries, SMEs are an important segment of the economy in the PRC. They 
contribute to economic growth, exports, tax revenues, and job creation. They generate about 60% 
of the PRC’s gross domestic product and 50% of fiscal and tax revenue. They represent more 
than 97% of total industrial enterprises and employ about 65% of the total workforce.2 Yet they 
find it difficult to access finance. SMEs suffer from a lack of collateral that banks nearly always 
require before providing a loan because of the perceived high risk of lending to them. This 
ultimately means that SMEs are burdened with a real lending rate of more than 15% per annum, 
much higher than the 3%–4% for state-owned enterprises (SOEs). Moreover, SMEs tend to be 
offered only very short tenors of 1–2 years. This makes it impossible for them to obtain properly 
structured loans for purposes such as capital investments. A lack of credit histories further 
impedes their access to finance. 
 
3.  Inadequate fintech framework. Challenges also arise from the inadequacy of the current 
regulatory and legal context when it comes to the use of fintech by the finance sector, and from a 
sector-based financial supervision system. The financial system is overseen primarily by two 
regulatory  agencies (China  Banking  and Insurance  Regulatory  Commission  and  the  China 
Securities Regulatory Commission), and the PBC. However, while their supervision fully covers 
commercial banking and traditional financial institutions, much of the realm of fintech-related 
finance providers remains outside their mandates. Hence, many emerging fintech platforms fall 
through regulatory gaps, and few guidelines or rules are in place to regulate fintech activities and 
tools. Fintech innovations play a key role in enhancing access to finance however, risks exist to 
the end-user of these solutions. These risks must be managed yet, consideration should also be 
given to for the overall benefits of enhancing access to finance.  
 
4.  Fintech-supporting regulatory tools not in place. While the PRC took steps to fill some 
regulatory gaps, these focused more on trying to control and remediate activities related to 
internet finance. A so-called "regulatory sandbox" (an enclosed environment, supported by a 
regulator, in which fintech innovation can take place) is one element that can help enable financial 
institutions to experiment with innovative financial products and services in a live operating 
 
environment.
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2019–2021. Manila. The TA first 
appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 25 October 2019. 
2  The definition of SMEs in the PRC is complex and involves a combination of (i) number of employees, (ii) industry, 
(iii) annual sales, and (iv) asset size. It stems from the 2003 Law on the Promotion of Small and Medium-Sized 
Enterprises. In general, medium-sized enterprises are those that employ 300–2,000 people, have annual sales of 
CNY30 million–CNY300 million, and own assets worth CNY40 million–CNY400 million. Companies with fewer than 
300 employees, less than CNY30 million in annual sales, and assets of less than CNY40 million are deemed small.

2 
5.  Biased lending practices. Banks are the dominant source of funding for enterprises in 
the country. State-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) control about 60% of banking assets and 
they also dominate the deposit market. They show a preference for lending to larger businesses 
and SOEs, while neglecting the growing financial needs of SMEs. Overall, the credit risk tolerance 
is low when it comes to lending to SMEs, and the banks’ risk incentive and risk assessment 
mechanisms are often biased, which results in credit officers being more interested in processing 
larger-size loans to SOEs to more easily meet internal performance targets. Balanced incentive 
systems are lacking.3 
 
6.  Fintech  overly  focused  on  short-term lending  to  microenterprises. The  current 
fintech  environment  in the  PRC  is generally  more  supportive  of  individual  consumers  and 
microlending. The business segment represented by SMEs beyond the micro segment remains 
less well served, lacking the full benefits from fintech innovations. While nonbanking financial 
institutions and other financial portals are more favorable to lending to SMEs, impediments exist, 
such as limited funding capacity, restraints on capital, and higher levels of nonperforming loans. 
In addition, credit risk assessment, credit methodologies, and credit delivery processes do not 
fully utilize fintech innovations. This is mainly true in the banking industry, which remains the 
largest source of loan funds available to SMEs. While financial institutions that adopted fintech 
innovations have had success in expanding access to credit and meeting the needs of various 
segments, the full benefits of fintech have yet to be realized. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: inclusive development via access to finance 
promoted.4 The TA will have the following outcome: impediments for SMEs in access to finance 
reduced.5 This will be accomplished through the implementation of three outputs. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Recommendations on easing access to finance for small and medium-
sized enterprises through the role of fintech created. The TA team will analyze the challenges 
that SMEs face in accessing credit in the PRC, with an emphasis on the role of fintech. The 
analysis will cover both the supply and demand sides of the financial market and explore the 
impact of fintech innovations on credit pricing, credit reporting, and credit evaluation, focusing 
especially on the practices of traditional stand-alone financial institutions and SOCBs. Surveys 
and roundtable discussions with SMEs will help obtain detailed information on their challenges in 
accessing credit. The TA team will also compile a list of international practices that successfully 
overcame similar access hurdles for SMEs, and which could be applied in the PRC, with a focus 
on fintech solutions. A national workshop to be held on fintech policy and innovations will help 
create a supportive framework. 
 
9.  Output 2: Policy recommendations for enhancing the regulatory fintech framework 
for  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  created.  The  TA  team  will  assess  the  PRC’s 
regulatory policy, supervisory, and institutional framework with regard to fintech and its potential

South China Morning Post. 29 August. 
4  Government of the PRC. 2016. 13th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development of the People’s

role in financing for SMEs. The assessment will include a desk review of earlier research and 
study reports in this field. The TA team will explore and recommend ways to effectively regulate 
and supervise fintech innovations in the PRC as they apply to access to finance for SMEs, and 
how to mitigate the risks of technology innovation for the sector and the consumers of financial 
services. The assessment will cover elements such as the use of bio-recognition in fintech, control 
of data use and protection against misuse, and finding the right balance between the rights of 
consumers and the benefits for the overall finance sector from the commercialization of financial 
innovations.  The  output  includes  a  workshop  for  policy  stakeholders  to  discuss  existing 
approaches to fintech-related regulatory policy, overlaps, gaps, and needs. It also includes a 
study tour to ADB member countries to explore first-hand some successful mechanisms for 
regulating fintech and its role in financing for SMEs. The TA team will prepare an ADB knowledge 
product on policy recommendations for outputs 1 and 2, to be distributed to counterparts, 
stakeholders, and industry groups. 
  
10.  Output 3: Framework governing the use of fintech innovations to expand access to 
credit developed. The TA team will assess the effectiveness of specific fintech innovations and 
models used in the PRC in supporting credit decision-making, risk management, and distribution. 
The output will focus on the technological mechanisms that can be applied to financial institutions 
and nonbank financial institutions when lending to small and medium-sized business (excluding 
the micro segment) to overcome impediments and biases. The TA team will conduct an inventory 
of existing fintech models for credit decision-making, risk management tools, and platforms for 
credit provision and funding intermediation, and compare their strengths and weaknesses. It will 
evaluate the potential of using fintech to broaden SMEs’ access to finance more fully within and 
outside the banking industry. The focus will be on new solutions such as using artificial intelligence, 
blockchains, natural language processing, and knowledge graphing. Use of fintech to improve the 
credit decision-making and risk management processes will be evaluated. One purpose of the 
output is to outline practical solutions that help remove the imprecision in current loan review 
processes and the human bias in decision-making. The TA team will test the rigor of commonly 
used model inputs and factors in the processing of credit for SMEs, identify elements of bias in 
lending to SMEs, and assess how technology solutions could help overcome such bias. It will 
stage an international conference to discuss the findings of outputs 2 and 3 and focus on fintech 
solutions for SMEs’ access to finance and the experience of the PRC. Finally, the team will 
prepare a knowledge product on the experience of the PRC in using fintech to develop SMEs’ 
access to finance that can be applied in other ADB member countries. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources)  and  $200,000  will  be 
financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund6 and 
administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff; administrative and logistic support to perform surveys and organize and manage training 
events, workshops, and conferences; access to data and required document sources; facilities 
for key meetings between the implementing agency and consultants; printing and distribution of 
project  material  to  PBC  staff;  assistance  in  coordinating  meetings  with  counterparts  and 
stakeholders; and other in-kind contributions. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
 
                                                
6  Financing partner: The Government of Luxembourg.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency is the PBC. The implementing agency 
is the Research Department of the PBC. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, 
and provide staff to act as resource persons in workshop and conferences, if needed. It will recruit 
one international consultant for a total of 5 person-months intermittent and one national consulting 
firm for a total of 12 person-months. The TA will be monitored and evaluated based on the 
implementation of activities and delivery of outputs as per the agreed timeline and budget. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $200,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development 
Partnership Fund; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
on a grant basis to the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Expanding Access to 
Finance for Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises through Financial Technology Innovations, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
